Gilma T. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 48 years old. Gilma is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Gilma owns & operates a business selling dried fish in the local community. Gilma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Gilma is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Gilma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Levi

texts.en:
Levi G. is currently in the business of selling cold and soft drinks and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of  soda to sell.  Levi is 29 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a resturant. 

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more crates of soda to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Mrs. Josephine J. is 55 years old and has eight children whole rely solely on her to provide for them, as she is a widower. Her main source of income is a rice farming business which she works hard to maintain. Josephine needs financial assistance and is now requesting a loan of Php 15,000 to finance her farm.

loans.use: To finance her rice farm.

loans.name: Vergelita

texts.en: Vergelita L., a resident of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato, tills her 1-hectare rice farm for a living. She is 42 years old, married and has two children. A member of CEVI since 2007, she thinks its program is very helpful to her and her fellow farmers, noting the lower interest rate offered. Now she is asking for a loan of Php13,000. The loan will be used to finance Vergelita’s farm.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en: Tessie felt relieved when she found a business partner with CEV. She said that its financing program helped lighten her burden. Tessie is a 54-year-old married woman and has six children. Her 1-hectare rice field is the source of her family’s income. She is in need of additional financial support. She asked to loan Php15,000 from CEV. This loan will truly help Tessie and her family in sustaining their farm.

loans.use: Additional financial support

loans.name: Melita

texts.en: Melita, a widow, is left with a 14-year-old child to take care of. She is 51 years old and works hard to sustain herself and her one child. Her 3 sows and 6 pigs currently compose her livestock. Hopefully, she would be able to grow her business. Melita asked to loan Php15, 000 to increase her working capital.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Amavi

texts.fr: Cette jeune dame est mariée à un transitaire et le couple a 03 enfants ; l’année dernière grâce à l’aide de son mari elle s’est lancée dans la vente de charbons de bois au Grand Marché de Lomé. Elle arrive à trouver sa part dans ce nouveau commerce où elle parvient à s’imposer. Elle s’approvisionne à Atakpamé, une ville située à des dizaines de kilomètres de Lomé. Elle est fière de pratiquer cette activité qu’elle juge intéressante ; elle dispose déjà une clientèle qui lui est fidèle. Actuellement elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour commander 30 sacs de charbon de bois. Le reste  du prêt servira à couvrir ses frais de transport vers Atakpamé.
texts.en:
This young lady is married to a freight broker, and the couple has three children. Last year, thanks to her husband’s help, she got started in selling charcoal at the Grand Market of Lomé. She manages to make a place for herself in this new business, where she is succeeding in becoming established. She stocks up in Atakpamé, a city located dozens of kilometers from Lomé. She is proud of operating in this business, which she finds interesting. She already has a customer base loyal to her. Currently, she’s requesting a WAGES loan to order 30 sacks of charcoal. The rest of the loan will be used to cover the costs of transport to Atakpamé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Annelyn

texts.en: Annelyn G. is thankful she doesn’t have to tend other people’s farm since she owns a hectare of rice field to attend to. She is 41 years old, married and has two children. Her rice field is the family’s source of income that’s why she makes it an effort to ensure her crops are growing healthy. To sustain her farm, Annelyn needs additional financial assistance. She asked to loan Php10, 000 from CEV.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret sells medicines and cosmetics in Lagos state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for the past 5 years. Margaret is 49 years old and married with 4 children. She hopes for a loan of N140,000 to purchase more cosmetics and medicines to sell. She says "thank you".

loans.use: To purchase more medicines and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en: Julieta is a rice farmer from Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She is 43 years old, married and has two children. Her eldest is now 25 years old. The 1-hectare rice field she owns supports her family. Julieta needs financing for her farm. She requested to loan 15,000 PHP from CEVI. The loan will be used to purchase farm supplies and other materials that she needs.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Fe

texts.en: Fe stands as a mother and father to her three children now that her husband has passed on. She is 63 years old and resides in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato where rice farming is one of the main livelihoods. Fe manages one and a half hectare of rice field herself. Her harvest reaches 80 to 100 sacks. To continue in her farming business, Fe needs additional financial support. She requested to loan Php10, 000. This loan will go to farm inputs and other farming necessities.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn T. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old. Evelyn is married and has three infant children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a specialized retail store where she sells homemade accessories in the local community. Evelyn has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Evelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en: Ofelia A., 55, is a single woman from Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She ventured into hog raising and rice farming. She currently owns one cow, two sows, and a hectare of rice field. Ofelia is a member of CEVI. According to her, its microinsurance service is helpful and she also learned a lot from Biblical reflections during monthly meetings. Ofelia needs to increase her working capital. She is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP. This loan will help finance her farm and support her hog-raising project.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy is 40 years old and married with seven children, ages 8 to 20 years. Six of her children go to school .She also takes care of additional family members. Prossy resides in and rents a one room house where she is staying with seven people. There is electricity, but no piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area in the outskirts of Kampala in Mulago. 

Prossy works seven days a week. She buys cosmetics and other hair relaxers from Kampala city shops and incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping. She pays a monthly rent of 50000/=.  She sells to all kinds of people Prossy has been in this business for 20 years and has been with MCDT for six years, servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group. She wants to use this loan to buy more cosmetics and hair relaxers. Prossy aspires to grow her business and start importing products directly.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and hair relaxers

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: Lorna T., a 36-year-old widow, is raising four children on her own. She invested in hogs to earn a living. Her income from raising hogs supplies the family’s needs. Lorna strives to maintain her business so she can also sustain her children’s education. She requests a loan of 15,000 PHP from CEVI. She will use the loan to finance her business.

loans.use: Financing her hog raising business

loans.name: Jukudu

texts.en:
Jukudu R. is currently in the business of selling products at a salon and is requesting a loan to purchase more hair materials to sell. Jukudu is 25 years old and is married with a husband who is an administrator. She has two children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase cold drinks and soft drinks to sell in the salon shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more hair materials  to sell

loans.name: Adjo

texts.fr: Cette femme vend uniquement des oeufs de poule dans sa maison à Kégué à Lomé. Elle a épousé un électricien bâtiment ; ces temps-ci les revenus du mari n’arrivent plus à couvrir tous les besoins financiers du foyer ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle s’est lancée l’année dernière dans le commerce d’œufs. Depuis 2 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité, cette dame arrive à aider son mari dans l’éducation de leurs 02 enfants. Elle vend en gros mais aussi en détail, et approvisionne les bars et restaurants du quartier. Elle a besoin en ce moment d’acheter 100 plateaux d’œufs ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle souhaite avoir un crédit de WAGES.

loans.use: achat de plateaux d'oeufs

loans.name: Gisèle

texts.fr: G. Gisèle est née en 1969 à Porto-Novo, Capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à GODOME Daniel revendeur, et mère de cinq enfants, Gisèle réside à Abomey-Calavi au Sud du Bénin. Gisèle et son mari supportent ensemble les charges de la famille. Gisèle vend le charbon de bois et les divers (pâtes alimentaires, boîtes de conserves, savons, haricot) à son domicile à Abomey Calavi.  C’est à Dantokpa à Cotonou, grand marché international du Bénin que Gisèle achète ses produits de commerce. Gisèle a déjà 10 ans d’expérience dans ce domaine. Gisèle ambitionne augmenter le volume de son activité, mais il lui manque de moyens financiers pour y arriver. C’est la raison pour laquelle Gisèle s’est rapprochée de ALIDé pour obtenir de financement.

loans.use: Achat de 40 sacs de charbons de bois

loans.name: Banke

texts.en: Banke sells clothes, sarongs, shoes and bags to make a living. This is her main source of income. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 46 years old and married with four children. She hopes for the loan amount of 140,000 NGN to purchase more clothes and sarongs to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Leilila

texts.en:
Leilila is a 58-year-old married woman from South Cotabato. She lives with her husband and their six children. She cultivates a hectare of rice field, which produces harvests three times a year. When it’s not time for harvest, Leilila maximizes her time by raising hogs to make up for her family’s daily needs.

Leilila has been with CEVI for more than two years now. She maintained her membership because the lower interest rate has been helpful to her. Now she is requesting a loan of 15 000 PHP. She will use this loan to finance her farm.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Ma. Cecilia

texts.en: 33-year-old Cecilia L. owns a hectare of rice field. She is married to Rey L. and they have 5 children, with 16 years old as the oldest. Her harvest experience varies from good to not so good. But she is thankful nonetheless especially if the price of rice is high during harvest time. Cecilia is in need of additional financial support. She requested to loan Php15, 000, which she will use to finance her farm. This loan will help Cecilia in her farming business.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita P. is a 41-year-old married woman from South Cotabato. She and her husband were blessed with four children to love and take care of. Lolita is into rice farming. She owns one hectare of rice field. Aside from that, she also manages a sari-sari store where she spends her time while waiting for harvest. Right now, Lolita’s business is doing well. A member of CEVI for more than two years now, she particularly likes the Savings and Insurance program and also the low interest rate offered. To maintain her business, Lolita requests a loan of 15,000 PHP from CEVI. This loan will be used to finance her farm and also to buy inventory for the store that she owns.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Jowena

texts.en: Jowena C., 31, lives with her husband of five years. She has a hectare of rice field to cultivate. Like other farmers, she needs financing to help grow her farm. That’s why she stayed with CEVI and is now on her second year with the MFI. Now she is requesting for a loan of 15,000 PHP. She will use the loan for farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en: 43-year-old Gemma E. lives with her husband and their 2 children, which are both in school. She manages 1 hectare of rice field in her hometown in South Cotabato. She joined CEV in 2007 and is very thankful for the financial service she was able to avail because she said it is a big help in her business. Now she is requesting to loan Php12, 000. The loan will be used to purchase farm inputs. Hopefully, Gemma will have a good harvest.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy U. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 36 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Mercy owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting fruits like bananas for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Mercy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to pay for services to increase crop yield. Mercy is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Alexer

texts.en:
MFI Staff Member Name
	Rose 
Date	24.09.09
Full Name Of Each Group Member	Prossy Nalwoga 
GROUP MEMBERS AND THEIR lOANS
Prossy  Nalwoga 	500,000
	
	
 	
Center No	70
Alexa is a 52 widowed with five children aged between 11 and 18 years. All her children go to school .She takes care of additional family members. Alexa resides and owns a one roomed house where she is staying with eight people. There is electricity no piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala in Kyebando Nsooba . Alexa works seven days a week. She buys her second hand shoes from owino Market and incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.  She pays monthly rent of 50000/=.  She sells and works to all categories of people Alexa has been in this business for ten  years and with MCDT for eight years, servicing her twentieth  loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more second hand shoes .Alexa is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and start import them directly

loans.use: To buy more second hand shoes

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Divina D., 37 years old, owns a 3/4-hectare (approx. 2-acre) rice field in Surallah, South Cotabato with a maximum harvest of 120 sacks. She has seven children and the eldest is 18 years old. She receives Php 100 per day from her tricycle but not enough to finance her rice field.

Divina is now requesting a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) to enable her to buy materials necessary for her rice field.

Divina joined CEVI in 2008 and says that it will help her a lot to sustain her children’s tuition fees. Also her farm will be financed with only a 2% interest rate, which is a lesser burden to repay.

loans.use: To use for farm financing

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
30-year-old Josie F. is managing a rice field in Surallah, South Cotabato. She’s married and has a 4-year old child. Her husband inherited 1 and 1/4 hectare rice field with 86 to 100 sacks per harvest.  Her husband also owns a T-shirt printing and print shop as another source of income. 

She needs an additional capital to purchase farm supplies and pay for using hand tractor in their farm business.  She’s requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. for Php 6,000.  CEVI offers the lowest interest rate and the loan would be of great help in financing her existing business.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Mindany

texts.en:
Mindany E., 33 years old, has business in rice farming and hog raising located in Surallah, South Cotabato.  The eldest of her 2 children is 12 years old.  She owns a hectare rice field, 12 fattening and 2 sows.  

For her to help finance her business, she makes a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. since it provides the lowest interest rate as compared to her previous experience from others and lessens her financing charge.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Mary Joe

texts.en:
Mary Joe V. owns and operates a specialized retail store selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in her community. She is 21 years old, married and has one small child. They are from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. Mary Joe has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 pesos a month.

In 2009, Mary Joe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Mary Joe is requesting a loan of 5,000 pesos which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Emely

texts.en:
Emely V. C. runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling food and daily use products in her community. She is 29 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Sagay, Camiguin. Emely has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 pesos a month.

In 2009, Emely joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Emely is requesting a loan of 4,000 pesos which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Sadaina

texts.en: Sadaina is a 37 married with four children aged between 6 and 16 years. All her children go to school .She takes care of additional family members. Sadaina resides and owns a one roomed house where she is staying with six people. There is electricity no piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala in Kitawuluzi. Sadaina works seven days a week. She buys her merchandise from Kikuubo one the busiest places in Kampala city and incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.  She pays monthly rent of 70000/=.  She sells and works to all categories of people Sadaina has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her twentieth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise .Sadaina  is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and start a whole sale shop.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise for her retail shop like suagr soap and salt

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda L. is living in Surallah, South Cotabato with rice farming and hog raising business since 2000.  She’s married and has 3 children, her eldest is 16 years old.  She has 1 sow, 10 piglets and a hectare rice field.  

She would like to ask for a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. worth Php 8,000.  She will use the loan to help support her business and could provide the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en: Kemi sells drinks, provisions and wine. She has been in this business for long. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. Kemi is 42 years old and married with 4 children. Kemi hopes for the loan amount of N140, 000 to purchase more drinks and provisions to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and provisions to sell

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
38-year old Anita F. manages a small sari-sari store which she rely on to supplement her income to buy the basic needs. Aside from that, she also manages a hectare of rice field and owns a in Surallah, South Cotabato.  She has 5 children and the eldest is 15 years old.  She started her business since 1992.

August 2008, she joins CEVI.  Now she’s requesting for a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to help finance her business.  The income she will receive is very helpful to continue send her children to school.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Angèle

texts.fr: G. Angèle est née en 1975 à Comè, au Sud du Bénin et est mariée à AWO Edgard, un soudeur. Mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés, Angèle réside à Abomey Calavi au Sud du Bénin depuis trois ans. Grâce au revenu de son activité de vente de matériels électriques (ampoules, réglettes, interrupteurs, etc.), des fournitures scolaires et de tissus, Angèle participe aux dépenses de la famille. Angèle achète ses produits de commerce à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin et à Lomé, pays voisin du Bénin ; et les revend à Cocotomey, à Cotonou. Angèle a déjà quinze ans d’expérience dans ce domaine. Pour continuer à développer son activité et plus tard créer une société de vente de matériels électriques, Angèle sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Angèle G. was born in 1975 in Comé, in the south of Benin, and is married to Edgard Awo, a welder. Angèle is a mother of 2 schooled children, and has been living in Abomey Calavi, in the south of Benin, for 3 years now. Her revenues made from the sale of electrical supplies (light bulbs, power bars, light switches, etc.), school supplies and fabrics, allowed Angèle to contribute to her family's expenditures. Angèle purchases her products in Dantokpa, a large international market in Benin, as well as in Lomé (in Benin's neighboring country of Togo); and resells them in Cocotomey, in Cotonou. Angèle has fifteen years of experience in this domain. To continue developing her current business, and to later create a sales company of electrical supplies, Angèle is requesting a loan with Alidé.

Translated from French by Dina Dumenko, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 30 power bars, 50 light bulbs, 30 light switches...

loans.name: Preciosa

texts.en:
Preciosa V.' main source of income comes from buying and selling scrap materials in her community. She is 55 years old, widowed and has three school-age children. They are from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin. Preciosa has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 2,000 pesos a month.

In 2009, Preciosa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Preciosa is requesting a loan of 4,000 pesos which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita E. started her business in rice farming and hog raising way back 1965.  Today she is already 63 years old who lives in Surallah, South Cotabato with 9 children.  She owns 1-hectare rice field manage by her son with an average harvest of 85 to 100 sacks.

She would like to ask for a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. worth Php 12,000.  She will use the loan to buy materials for the farm and payment for land preparation.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia P. joined CEVI in August 2008. She’s now 61 years old with four children. She's living in Surallah, South Cotabato. She receives a daily income from her sari-sari (variety) store. She also has three harvests each year on her 1-hectare rice field. She sometimes had a good harvest and sometimes not due to irrigation cut-off and a pest attack.

She’s requesting a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. for her to sustain her business. With CEVI, she will be able to finance her farm with lower interest.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn F. is a 58-year-old woman, who is blessed with three children.  She has a rice farming and hog raising business in Surallah, located in the province of South Cotabato, Philippines.  Evelyn owns a one and a half-hectare rice field, and one sow.  Evelyn started her business in 1968, and she has a good return during harvest time, especially when prices are high. 

Evelyn joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in August 2008.  Today she needs a loan of 10,000 PHP from CEVI to refinance her business with a lower interest rate.

loans.use: Refinancing

loans.name: Rose Jean

texts.en:
34-year old Rose Jean N. lives in Surallah, South Cotabato where she has hog raising and rice farming businesses. She started her businesses in 2000. Each year she can harvest three times but sometimes a crop fails due to pest attack. She also earns PHP 300-800 per day in her sari-sari (variety) store that helps provide for the basic needs of her family.

Rose Jean is requesting a loan of PHP 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. which will enable her to buy farm inputs, pig feed, and groceries for her sari-sari store.

loans.use: To use for farm financing, pig feed and groceries for her store

loans.name: Abosede

texts.en: Abosede has poultry farm where she rears birds to make a living. She is 45 years old and married with 2 children. She is requesting for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more poultry birds. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry birds

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica N., 47 years old, is from Surallah, South Cotabato where she manages a two-hectare rice field that yields three crops each year.  The harvest, her main source of income, is very helpful in sustaining her family. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and is now requesting a loan of Php 10,000 to buy farm necessities. To be able to finance her business with a lower interest rate from CEVI  allows Veronica to run a more profitable enterprise.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a 45 married with seven children aged between 19 and 31 years. Three of her children go to school .She takes care of additional family members. Mary resides and rents a two roomed house where she is staying with four people. There is no electricity and piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala in Naguru kasenke. Mary works seven days a week. She buys sweet potatoes from Nakawa market one the busiest markets in Kampala city and doesn’t  incur extra transport costs to and from shopping as she buys from her place of work from delivery trucks .  She only  pays daily market dues of 700/= a day   She sells and to all categories of people Mary  has been in this business for fifteen years and with MCDT for eight years, servicing her sixteenth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of sweet potatoes .Mary  is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and start going directly to villages to buy them..

loans.use: to buy sacks of sweet  potatoes

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
36-year old Edgar B. runs rice farming business and a sari-sari store.  His 1-hectare rice field is the primary source of income while his sari-sari store provides the daily needs of his family.  His business started since 1995. 

He would like to request a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to purchase farm supplies and groceries.  He will be able to help pay the tuition fee of his nephew with the income he will receive from his business.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Felisicima

texts.en: Felisicima Y. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin. She is 50 years old, is married, and has eight adult children. Felisicima owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Felisicima joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Felisicima is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Fumi

texts.en: Fumi sells building materials in retail to her customers. She is 43 years old and married with 3 children. She is a hard working woman. She hopes for the loan amount of N140, 000 to purchase more building materials to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Annet Namutebi's Group

texts.en: Annete is a 42 married with six children aged between 11 and 21 years. All her children go to school .She takes care of additional family members. Annete resides and owns a four roomed house where she is staying with eight people. There is no electricity and piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala in Lugala Lungujja zone. Annete works seven days a week. She buys firewood from Owino market one the busiest markets in kampala city and incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.  She  pays daily market dues of 700/= a day   She sells and to all categories of people Annete   has been in this business for six years and with MCDT for one week, servicing her first loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more firewood .Annete  is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and start another business of second hand clothes..

loans.use: To buy more firewood

loans.name: Sherifatu

texts.en: Sherifatu has been selling drinks and sachet water in wholesale and retail for long. She is a hard working woman and she is determined to lift her family above poverty. She 49 years old and married with 5 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more drinks and sachet water to sell. She is indeed grateful to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and sachet water

loans.name: Allen Mununuzi Group

texts.en:
Allen, a 27-year-old married mother of five children between one and nine years of age, four attending school, resides and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala in Lugala Kosovo zone. She also takes care of additional family members. Allen owns and shares with eight people a five-room house that has electricity but no piped-in water. The family gets three meals a day.

Allen works seven days a week buying charcoal from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala, incurring transport costs as well as daily market dues of 700/= a day. In business for eight years, she sells to all categories of people. Having recently joined MCDT, she is requesting her first loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. Allen aspires to expand her business and start buying her charcoal directly from the villages.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Janet Nalukwago's Group

texts.en:
Janet is a 25-year-old single mother of one child aged 6 years who goes to school. Janet also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and owns a five-roomed house where she lives with five people. There is electricity but no piped water at home The family gets three meals a day.

Janet resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala in Lugala Kosovo zone. She works seven days a week. She buys vegetables and fruit from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city, and incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping. She also pays daily market dues of 700/= a day.

Janet sells to all categories of people. She has been in this business for three years and with MCDT for one week. She is servicing her first loan and wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of onions and baskets of oranges, tomatoes and pineapples.

Janet is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and wants to start going to buy directly from villages.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Ric

texts.en:
Ric D. S. is from the village of Gata Diot, Clarin Misamis Occidental. He is 30 years old. Ric is married with 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Ric owns & operates a business venture in the services sector, operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for his business comes primarily from providing hairdressing services to local community members. Ric has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Ric joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation as well as his ability to engage in business activities. Ric has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC. Ric is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase equipment to improve his business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Ric from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase equipment to improve the business

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Esterlita D. G. is from the village of Tugas, Tangub city. She is 50 years old and is married. To make a living, Esterlita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a "sari-sari" retail store. While not her only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for her business comes primarily from selling different products such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap and etc.,in the local community. Esterlita has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Esterlita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Esterlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Esterlita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the  loan taken out by Esterlita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve her family's general living conditions and save for future needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Arnulfo

texts.en: Arnulfo G. is from the village of Lapasan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 38 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Arnulfo owns and operates a business providing motor transportation services to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Arnulfo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. Arnulfo is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase equipment to improve his business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase equipment to improve his business

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
In God We Trust is a group of five borrowers led by Titus N., a high school graduate, who is married with two children aged 6 and 11 years with educational levels of kindergarten 3rd grade. Titus also cares for a nephew and a stepson. Titus lives and works in Gaye Town, Old Road, Monrovia, Liberia. This is a community that is mixed with both poor and middle class Liberians.

Titus’ business is clothing, buying used clothes wholesale and selling to his customers in Gaye Town. He has been running his business for more than a year. He started this business with a few pieces of used clothing but now he has more than one hundred pieces.

Selling a good product is the means of attraction Titus uses to get more customers. The rainy season makes business slow because Titus doesn't have a shelter for his business; he usually goes around to sell.

Titus’ dream is to grow his business until he can build a larger permanent shop. He is taking the loan to buy additional used clothes wholesale to serve his customers and improve his business. With the profits from his business he dreams of sending his children to school and building a house of his own.

loans.use: To buy additional used clothes wholesale

loans.name: Patience Group

texts.en:
Patience Group is a group of five borrowers led by Patrick G., a university student, and single father with two children. Both of them are 10 years old and they are in the 5th grade. Patrick lives and works in West Point, a very crowded and poor community with a high crime rate. West Point is also filled with fishermen and it is south of and close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Patrick’s business is general goods like door locks, hinges, nails, files, spoons, combs and clothes pegs that he buys wholesale and sells retail to the residents of West Point.

Patrick started by buying rice by the bag and selling it retail but later realized he has to run a bigger business than that, so he started his general goods business. He always sells at a low price to his customers and gives them good service. That’s why the customers always want to come and buy from him.

Patrick needs this loan in order to buy more goods to improve his business. He hopes to grow his business and become a big business person in society and dreams of providing himself and his family with a better life and educating his children for the future.

loans.use: To buy more goods to improve business

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites S. V. is a resident of an island village in the beautiful town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 42 years old and married to Severino who is her partner in business. She is a mother to eight: seven sons and an only daughter. She is a woman with clear foresight of the future of her family.

It is more than a decade already that Marites has been running the fishing business but, due to insufficient capital, sometimes she encounters problems regarding her business needs. In 2009, she decided to join ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, with hopes of getting access to capital for her dying business. When she received her first loan, she invested it in her fishing business. It was successful and the business now brings her a good income to sustain the needs of her family.

Marites has a fish cage where she cultures small fish until they are ready to harvest and sell in the market. She has regular customers already and sometimes she roams around the village and even in the market to sell fish.

Now on her 2nd loan, she proposes a loan of 10,000 PHP as additional capital for her fishing business. The amount will be used to pay for a bundle of fishnet, fifty pieces of bamboo and payment for the labor of making the fish cage. She hopes to expand her business and be able to save for the future of her children, especially their school needs.

loans.use: To buy items needed go make a fish cage

loans.name: Bola

texts.en: Bola is 48 years old and married with four children. For the last ten years, she has been selling beans, rice and other provisions. Bola hopes for the loan amount of N 80,000 to purchase more inventory. She would like to say "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Apai

texts.en:
Apai J. is currently in the business of selling earrings at the shop and is requesting a loan to purchase necklaces to sell.  Apai is 25 years old and is married to a policeman. She has four children who are all attending school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase necklaces to sell.

loans.name: Dudu

texts.en:
Dudu S. is currently in the business of selling baking and selling bread  and is requesting a loan to purchase more baking materials .  Dudu is 45 years old and is Married with a husband that is a business man. She has 5 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children and provide them with scholarstic materials.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more baking materials

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
Erma C. is a woman who is full of determination and faith, with the goal of bringing her family out of the spiral of poverty that hinders their way to success. She is a young, 24 year old mother to her daughter and is happily living with her husband Bernard, who is her partner in the business. She lives on an island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal Province in the Philippines.

As a newly married woman, life was not easy for Erma. She needs to think of the future of her child. She is already running a General Store but it has not been as productive as expected. She needs to venture into another business, but has no capital to use. Therefore, she decided to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in the hopes of getting access to capital for her business.

When she received her previous loan, she carefully utilized it as capital for her fishing business. It is her husband who goes fishing using fish nets. The fish he catches is sold in the village and even in the market. Their supply of fish to sell in the town is great and earns her a good income. She wants to improve her business and wants to invest more in it.

For this, her next loan, she is requesting an amount of 10,000 PHP to buy bundles of fishnets and other fishing gear. She is hopeful that with the support of ASHI and with the trust of KIVA lenders, she can expand her business and be able to attain her dreams slowly and methodically. She also aspires to save for the future of her children.

loans.use: To buy bundles of fishnets and other fishing gear.

loans.name: Oluwabumi

texts.en: Oluwabumi is 35 years old and a mother of two. She is hard working and loves her hair products retail business. Specifically, she sells hair extensions and relaxers. Oluwabumi hopes for a loan in the amount of N 100,000 to purchase more inventory to sell. She is grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and relaxers to sell

loans.name: Elizerbeth

texts.en:
Elizerbeth J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal  and is requesting a loan to purchase fox poles to sell.  Elizerbeth is 28 years old and is Married with a husband that is a police man . She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build store for charcoal and fox poles. 

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase fox poles to sell

loans.name: Fumi

texts.en: Fumi sells drinks and sachet water in her shop, and she has been in this business for the past 10 years. Forty years old and married with five children, she hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more drinks and sachet water to sell. Fumi says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and sachet water to sell

loans.name: Tolokeze

texts.en:
Tolokeze J., currently in the business of selling green vegetables, is requesting a loan to purchase fish to sell. Twenty-eight years old and married to a policeman, Tolokeze has two children, both students. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop and buy a motor boat for fishing.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Tamtamneh Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Tamtemneh group. They are small scale businesspeople in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva to seek a loan of Le 500,000 for each for the very first time to enable them improve their businesses. With such a loan, they will be able to expand their businesses both in size and quality. In this way, they can make more sales and better profit. Consequently, their living standards will improve – they will be able to better support their school going children in terms of feeding, clothing and meeting schools expenses. 

Mariama L. (left) is the leader of this group. Mariama was born in Magburaka town, thirty-five years ago. She is married with four children.  Two of her children are in Junior Secondary School II (JSS II), the other is in JSS III and the other is nursery school. Mariama sells market food, rice, cooking oil etc. She has been in this business for more than six years now.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Coumba

texts.fr: Madame S. Coumba est agée de 35 ans. Elle est divorcée et est mère de 3 enfants. Pour subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants, Madame S. décida, il y'a 5 mois de cela, de se lancer dans la vente de légumes et de vêtements. Avec l'approche de la fête de Korité et de l'ouverture des classes, Madame S. sollicite un prêt de 100 000 Frs cfa. De l'argent de ce crédit, elle compte acheter des vêtements en Gambie qu'elle revendre dans sa localité et espère renforcer ses activités afin de gagner plus pour mieux préparer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants

loans.use: acheter des vêtements "prêts à porter" en Gambier et venir les vendre à Thiès

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 46 years old and married with five children. For the past 15 years she has run a business selling foodstuffs such as tubers of yam, rice and garri. Margaret uses her years of business experience to attract and retain her customers. She is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Saiberia Group

texts.en:
Betty M., age 41, is a divorcee with four children.  She sells clothes, fabrics and shoes. She started this business  5 years ago and works daily from 9am until 8pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $309. 

This will be Betty’s 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She hopes for a loan to increase on her business. 
\t
Betty will share this loan with her loan group, Saiberia, which totals 21 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Betty is 1st on the right front row.

loans.use: To increase on her business

loans.name: Ibaba

texts.en:
Ibaba R. is 20 years old and married to a businessman. They have two school-aged children. Ibaba is currently in the business of selling maize flour, and is requesting a loan to purchase beans and rice to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a motorbike for transporting her goods to the store.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Unity Family Group

texts.en:
This is Mabinty C., Posseh K., Sayo K., Cyril I. K. and Fatu C., and they have called their group Unity Family. This is the first loan this group is accessing from Kiva through SMT. With this loan, they will be able to improve their businesses in size and quality. Consequently, their sales and profit margins will improve – they will then be able to better support their school-aged children in terms of food, clothes, school fees and other school-related charges.

Mabinty C. (second from right) is the leader of this group. Mabinty was born in Magbontho, near Magburaka town, in northern Sierra Leone. She is 48 years old, and married with seven children who attend primary or secondary school. Mabinty sells palm oil, the most popular cooking oil in Sierra Leone, and has been in this business for more than 25 years. With this loan, she will buy more palm oil, rice and groundnuts/peanuts.

(Attached on the left is a group member who was not present for the group photograph.)

loans.use: To buy more palm oil, rice and groundnuts/peanuts

loans.name: Clementina

texts.en: Clementina sells foodstuffs and provisions. She is 33 years old and married with 4 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and provisions to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and provisions to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose S. is currently in the business of selling used clothes and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes to sell. Rose is 28 years old and is married to a husband who is a teacher. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to set up a bar to generate more profit.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr: Monsieur Moussa N. est agé de 38 ans et il est marié, père de 2 enfants. C'est un jeune maçon et en plus de son métier, il gére une cantine où il vend de l'aliment de bétail et etc. Pour diversifier ses revenus et accroitre ses activités, il pense se lancer dans l'aviculture. C'est ainsi qu'il sollicite un prêt de 200 000 Frs cfa. Avec l'argent de crédit, il compte  acheter tout le necesaire pour pouvoir démarrer l'activité
texts.en:
Mr. Moussa N. is 38 years old, married and the father of 2 children. He is a young mason and in addition to his trade, he manages a canteen where he sells cattle feed. In order to diversify his income and grow his business, he has decided to launch an aviculture (bird-raising) business. It is for this reason that he is requesting a loan of 200,000 FCFA. With this loan, he intends to buy all of the necessities for this start-up business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For bird-raising business.

loans.name: Sapoben Ii Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Sapoben II group. Members of the this group are small-scale businesspeople in the town of Magburaka, in the Tonkolili district, northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan from SMT/Kiva for the first time. Each is requesting a loan of Le 500,000 to improve his/her business, consequently improving his/her standard of living.

Abdul T. K. (second from left) is the leader of this group. Abdul was born in Magburaka town about thirty-six years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and they have four children. Three of Abdul’s children are attending primary schools and the other is in nursery school. Abdul sells used clothing. He has been in this business since 1992.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda S. is from the village of Unidos. She is 52 years old. Florenda is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Florenda owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from cultivating coconut trees and harvesting their fruit for sale. Florenda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Florenda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. Florenda is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in further expanding the business. This will be the 13th loan taken out by Florenda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Top-Up Group

texts.en:
This is Unisa K. and Mummy G. of the Top-up Group. They are small scale businesspeople in Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. They have received several loans from Kiva through SMT.   They always repay their loans in full. Their previous loan was for Le 800,000 each. This helped them a lot. They were able to make a lot of profit from the loan, thus able to solve many of their problems. Today, they are requesting a loan of Le 1,800,000 to add to their businesses.

Unisa K. (right) is the leader of this group. Unisa was born in Lunsar small town, in northern Sierra Leone. He is twenty-eight years of age, married to a businesswoman and they have one child who is in class III. Unisa has been a businessman since childhood days, he sell top-up card for all five mobile networks in the country. He also sells batteries, candles, cigarettes, lollipops, kerosene and many more. Unisa’s business has grown a great deal as a result of SMT/Kiva Lenders’ support. He started with a small stall, selling only cigarette but has now built himself a kiosk and included a lot of items for sale into his kiosk.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Harriet Namukwaya Group

texts.en: H. is a 38 married  with six   children aged 6 and 17 years. Her children go to school .She takes care of additional family members. H.  resides and owns a six roomed house where she is staying with four people. There is electricity and no piped water at home  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala in Lugala lungujja zone. H. works seven days a week. She buys her chicken feds from Owino market one of the busiest markets in kampala city and incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.  She doesn’t pay rent as she rears from her home She sells and to all categories of people H. has been in this business for nine years and with MCDT for one week, servicing her first loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of chicken feeds. Janet is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and start rearing 1000 chicken.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of  chicken feeds

loans.name: Kuburat

texts.en: Kuburat sells sarongs of various colours and shapes. She is 34 years old and married with 3 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs

loans.name: Claude

texts.en: Claude is a 51-year-old married man with 2 children. He has been working as home painter since 1999 to earn income to better satisfy the needs of his family. After 10 years, Claude is requesting to borrow $400 to renovate his business tools to be able to gratify the demand of his clients.

loans.use: renovate his business tools

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn T. is from the village of Unidos. She is 45 years old. Jovelyn is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Jovelyn owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing mechanical services to local community members. Jovelyn has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Jovelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Jovelyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 14th loan taken out by Jovelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mamusu Group

texts.en:
This is Fatmata K., Fatu K. and Hawa C.. They call their group Mamusu group. These entrepreneurs have received several loans from Kiva through SMT.  The previous loans have had meaningful impacts in the lives of these people. The last loan they received from Kiva through SMT was for Le 800,000.00 each. Now, they are requesting a loan of Le 1,000,000.00 each to enable them further strengthen their businesses.

Fatmata K. (right) is the leader of this group. Fatmata is thirty-five years of age. She was born in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a tailor. The two of them have two children. One of their children is in Junior Secondary School II (JSS II) and the other is in class V. Fatmata sells bread and she has been in this business for more than ten years now. With this loan, she will be able to buy bags of flour, sugar and other working ingredients.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a single man living with his parents and 3 brothers. He is 22 years old. In 2006, he opened a curtain shop as his own business. Today, Hassan is requesting a loan of US$ 800 to buy merchandise for his work to be able to keep on with his business by increasing his sales and also his income.

loans.use: buy merchandise

loans.name: Zaiat

texts.en: Zaiat sells cooked foods like eba, moimoi, fufu, she has been in this business for long. She is 40 years old and married with 7 children. She lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. She hopes for the loan amount of N140, 000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Harriet Namukwaya Group

texts.en:
Sylvia is 32, married with three children aged between 7 months and 10 years. Her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. Sylvia resides in and rents a one-roomed house where she is staying with four people. There is no electricity or piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

Sylvia resides and works in semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala in Lugala Masanafu zone. Sylvia works seven days a week. She buys her cream relaxers and cosmetics from Kampala city shops in Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala city and incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.

Sylvia doesn’t pay rent as she works from her home. She works upon all categories of people. Sylvia has been in this business for nine years and with MCDT for just one week, servicing her first loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more cream relaxers and cosmetics. Sylvia is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting a bridal salon.

loans.use: to buy more cream relaxers and cosmetics

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita A. is from the village of Mangidkid. She is 53 years old. Carmelita is married and has 9 adult children. To make a living, Carmelita owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Carmelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Carmelita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Tamemgbo Group

texts.en:
These people are Abdulai K., Mahawa G., Kadiatu K., Fatmata S. and Alie K.. They named their group Tamemgbo, a Temne phrase meaning “let us just have a try”. These entrepreneurs have received several loans from SMT. The previous loans have had meaningful impacts in the lives of these people. The last loan they received from SMT was for Le 800,000 each. Now, they are requesting a loan of Le 1,000,000 each to enable them to further strengthen their businesses.

Abdulai K. (right) is the leader of this group. Abdulai is approximately sixty-two years of age. He was born in a village called Pat Bama, in northern Sierra Leone. He is married to a businesswoman and they have seven children. Six of Abdulai’s children are attending schools, five in secondary schools and one in primary school. Abdulai sells used clothes and has been in this business for over forty years now.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou D., une femme mariée demeurant à Thies au Sénégal, est une couturière agée de 39 ans.  En plus de sa profession, elle s'active dans le commerce de tissus, sac, vetements etc pour renforcer ses activités et accroitre ses revenus. C'est ainsi qu'elle sollicite un pret de 200 000 frs cfa. Avec l'argent de ce crédit, elle compte se ravitailler pour satisfaire sa clientèle vue l'approche de la fete de Korité et de l'ouverture des classes ainsi de se positionner et de gagner de nouveaux marchés.

loans.use: acheter des tissus, sacs, chaussures, vetements etc et les revendre

loans.name: Ngorongoro Group

texts.en:
Mohamed I., age 37, is single with one daughter of 17 years. He has had a business selling new bags (shopping and traveling bags) since 2005 and works daily from 10am until 6pm. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around $60.

This will be Mohamed’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He hopes for a loan to increase stock of his bags.

Mohamed will share this loan with his loan group, Ngorongoro, which totals 19 members. The members of the group hold each other responsible in paying back the loan. In the picture, Mohamed is the one in front.

loans.use: To buy more bags of different designs

loans.name: Rose Mary

texts.en:
Rose Mary B. is from the village of Balanlinao. She is 33 years old. Rose Mary is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Rose Mary owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from cultivating decorative trees for sale. Rose Mary has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rose Mary joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rose Mary has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Rose Mary is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Rose Mary from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Yetunde

texts.en: Yetunde is happily married with 3 children and she is 35 years old. She sells medicines. She has been in this business for the past 10 years. She is requesting the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Elena’s dream for her three young children, who are now aged between 2 to 15 years old, is to have them graduate from college, be gainfully employed, and have a good life. Providing her family with financial security, raising their standard of living and ultimately moving them out of poverty is what motivates Elena T. to work hard with her husband to earn a good living for their family. Elena is 37 years old, married to Gadiel T. and, with their three children, live in the village of Sitio Anahaw, Barangay Miranda, Hinigaran City, Negros Occidental. The couple work cooperatively in their salted-egg business. He buys the eggs and makes the salted eggs and she sells them. Because of her earnestness to lift her family out of poverty and to achieve her dreams, Elena joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 so that she could access capital to start a business that could support her family. She went through the required seminars and, when she got her loan, she opened a general store adjacent to her house. Over the years, Elena built a good credit record and was able to borrow bigger amounts because she proved that her cash flow was able to afford the weekly installments. The bigger loans gave her the opportunity to diversify into another business venture, so she and her husband decided to invest in a salted-egg business; he made them and she sold them in her general store and distributed to other outlets in the community and neighboring towns. Elena also went into food-vending which she sold in her general store. From her different business activities, Elena earns an average profit of PHP 15,000 per month which she uses to pay for their household expenses and the education of her children; the balance she puts back as additional capital for her different ventures. Elena’s previous loan of Php 19,500 was used as additional capital for her business and it was fully paid on time. For her 9th loan she proposes to borrow the same amount - Php 19,500 to boost her salted-egg production. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her salted-egg business
